awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An integrated model-proxy approach to understanding Western US hydroclimate change since the last glacial period
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding what processes drive changes in rainfall along the U.S. West Coast is essential for predicting future water availability in this densely populated and agriculturally productive part of the country. However, given the short duration of direct meteorological observations (~100 years), it is beneficial to reconstruct past changes in rainfall over longer time periods (i.e., thousands of years) in order to uncover the potential sensitivity of water resources in the Western U.S to future climate change. This research project combines measurements of ancient groundwater and state-of-the-art climate model experiments to both quantify and understand the dynamical drivers of hydrological change along the American West Coast during the last ice age (i.e., the Last Glacial Maximum or LGM, ~25,000 years ago). This project also includes a comprehensive public outreach component, involving the creation of a museum exhibit for display at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). In collaboration with the University of Colorado Boulder, the researchers will lead an interdisciplinary course for students to design and prototype a museum exhibit that brings to life the radically different atmospheric circulation and rainfall patterns present during the LGM.
The first research component of this project involves a field campaign to collect groundwater samples from a network of wells within the Columbia Plateau Aquifer system in northeastern Oregon and southeastern Washington, which will provide a much-needed quantitative constraint on LGM hydroclimate in the data-poor Pacific Northwest. A new analytical technique for high-precision measurements of dissolved noble gas concentrations and Krypton and Xenon isotope ratios within the groundwater will be employed to reconstruct past temperature and regional water table depth. The second research component of the project involves climate model experiments using NCAR’s Community Earth System Model version 1.2 (CESM1) to build upon existing fully equilibrated climate simulations to study the influence of different LGM boundary conditions (ice sheet albedo/topography, greenhouse gases, orbital forcing, etc) on North Pacific atmospheric circulation and the intensity, variability, and landfalling orientation of moisture-rich storms known as Atmospheric Rivers (ARs). The project also includes a series of time-slice experiments, simulating both deglacial and glacial conditions, to examine the transient response of ARs and western North American hydroclimate to shrinking and growing continental ice sheets. Finally, detailed comparisons will be made between these model simulations and the proxy reconstructions of Pacific Northwest water table depths.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This interdisciplinary and collaborative project supported the reconstruction of past water table depth in the North American Pacific Northwest using a new geochemical technique, drawing on novel climate model simulations to evaluate model-data agreement and explore fundamental climate-hydrogeology interaction. Groundwater is a vital resource to society, providing drinking water to billions of people and supporting nearly half of the water demand of global agriculture. Better understanding the susceptibility of groundwater levels to climate forcing is critical for forecasting future groundwater availability and managing aquifer resources. While groundwater is represented in the Earth system models used to simulate future climate change, it is difficult to validate these models using historical data, since the historical record of groundwater levels is largely limited to the past century, during which time groundwater levels have changed because of human activity (e.g., groundwater pumping) and climate change. Thus, the main goal of this project was to reconstruct groundwater levels (i.e., water table depth) using a new geochemical technique to test the basic response of an aquifer system to a major hydroclimate change: a shift from drier to wetter conditions (lower to higher precipitation rates) during the transition out of the last ice age.

We collected groundwater samples from a network of municipal wells in the Palouse Basin Aquifer (Washington, Idaho, USA) for analysis of krypton and xenon isotopes, measured using a new high-precision technique at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. Briefly, because gravity leads to a depth-proportional enrichment in heavy gases in porous media, krypton and xenon isotope ratios preserve a signal that quantitatively records the depth to the water table, below the land surface, at the time and place of groundwater recharge. By measuring these dissolved gases in fossil groundwater, and applying a physical model, past water levels can be reconstructed with high accuracy. In this project, radiocarbon of dissolved inorganic carbon was used for groundwater dating, and bulk noble gas abundances were measured for reconstruction of past temperature. These analyses showed that water table depth was remarkably stable in the Palouse Basin, changing by less than one meter on average throughout the last deglaciation, during which time mean annual surface temperature rose by 5-6 degrees Celsius. Comparing these results to independent transient climate model simulations revealed close agreement (the model also showed a negligible change in water table depth across this time period). Using the same model and previous data from southern California, there was similarly close data-model agreement showing a large decline in water table depth (~18 m) in response to a decrease in precipitation. Together, these independent proxy and model findings point to divergent behavior of shallow and deep aquifers to climate forcing, providing evidence of a feedback that operates at shallow depth, which has been suggested theoretically and observed in some modern settings but never before demonstrated to operate over the long timescale and large extent of climatic change accompanying the last deglaciation in western North America.

In addition to the core analysis of past groundwater responses to climate in the Pacific Northwest, this work supported the training of a postdoc, the applicaton of a thermodynamic theory to consider the amplication of warmign on land versus sea from beyond the historical instrumental record, the reconstruction of temperature in western Europe from dissolved noble gases in groundwater from the last glacial maximum, and the reconstruction of water table depth and temperature in the Tucson Basin in a project led by a graduate student. This work supported the lead PI in developing a new method and setting up a new lab and provided opportunities for the PIs to contribute to an undergraduate course aimed at visually demonstrating hydroclimatic and atmospheric changes in western North America during the last deglaciation through the creation of museum exhibits. Ultimately, this undergraduate course led to the creation of a permanent exhibit at the National Center for Atmospheric Research that is on public display.
